Award.AwardTitle: INSPIRE Track 1: Human reasoning and learning in a complex but tractable decision-making paradigm

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This INSPIRE award is partially funded by the Robust Intelligence Program in the Division of Information and Intelligent Systems in the Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering and the Perception, Action, and Cognition Program in the Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences in the Directorate for Social, Behavioral, and Economic Sciences.

This project studies a hallmark of human intelligence, namely the ability to think ahead. Anticipating the consequences of one's own actions and those of others is of crucial importance in areas as diverse as business negotiations, military strategy, and teaching. In each of these domains, the quality of one's decisions depends on the quality of one's mental simulations of event sequences, which might be limited by cognitive capacity limitations, one's grasp of the complexities of the decision space, or both. The project's goal is to identify the factors that affect people's performance in thinking ahead, and investigate to what extent this performance can be improved through training. The project ties into the study of heuristics (general rules used by decision-makers) in psychology and behavioral economics.

Thinking ahead is difficult to measure and model in real-world problems. Therefore, the investigator has developed a two-person strategic decision-making task as a controllable experimental environment. Participants take turns to put tokens on a 4x11 board and try to get four of their own tokens in a row. The rules are unfamiliar to subjects, yet easy to learn. The size of the state space for this task is of the order of 10^20, much smaller than that of chess (~10^47), yet of appreciable complexity and much too large for humans to easily grasp. The investigators have "weakly solved" this task using an improved version of alpha-beta pruning. It can most likely also be solved strongly, which means that one can determine in any given position whether any given decision is an error. Human data will be collected in three task modes: one in which the subject is given a position and has to win in a set number of moves; human versus computer; and human versus human. The investigators will track subjects' eye movements, which could reveal aspects of planning and perhaps even serve to visualize the process of mental simulation.

An important component of the project will be computational modeling of the data. Humans cannot think ahead to the end of the task, so we hypothesize that they use simple features of positions (heuristics) to value certain moves over others. Examples of features could be the presence of a three-in-a-row, or of an adjacent, open-ended two-in-a-row. Preliminary human data suggest "strategic blind spots" created by the application of the incorrect heuristics. The investigators aim to predict the probability that a subject will in a given position make a particular move, based on features of the position that would be created by that move, as well as the subject's limited depth of reasoning. The resulting model will allow to quantitatively address the question of whether learning mostly serves to increase one's depth of reasoning or to refine one's palette of heuristics. The behavioral and eye movement data will lay the foundation for studies of the neural substrates of reasoning in complex decision-making contexts.

The project is positioned at the intersection of computer science, cognitive psychology, management and decision science, and education, and has the potential to contribute to each of these fields. In the long run, the project might be able to contribute to understanding and perhaps avoiding failures to think "out of the box" in real-life problem-solving. Moreover, strategic tasks like the one used in this project could serve as a mini-environment for testing hypotheses about teaching methods.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The long-term goal of this research project is to understand how people make complex decisions, such as negotiating, military strategy or planning a career or research program. To make these decisions, people need to “think ahead”, i.e. mentally simulate the consequences of sequences of actions, and choose the action which ultimately yields the most desirable outcome. While artificial intelligence algorithms are now incredibly proficient at doing so (e.g. AlphaGo, AlphaZero), it is poorly understood how humans solve such problems. We approach this question by studying human behavior in a deterministic, two-player game similar to tic-tac-toe, combined with computational modeling.

 

Our previous experiments within this project consisted of human participants playing against each other, playing against computers, solving two-choice problems, or evaluating positions. We also built a computational model that could account for individual human decisions in these paradigms as well as for their reaction times and eye movements. To our knowledge, we are the first to build a computational model for human decisions in such a large decision space. 

 

In the reporting period, we performed more data analysis on two newer experiments (briefly mentioned in the previous RPPRs): (1) Turing test: human participants viewed a video fragment of a game, and had to judge whether it was played by two humans or two computers. The computer players were simulated based on our computational model of human play, so if our model were perfect, the Turing test would succeed: there would be no noticeable difference between two humans and two computers. Obviously, our model is not perfect, and the Turing test has helped us to quantify in what ways our model still differs from human play. (2) Reconstruction: in the psychology literature on planning in chess, a popular paradigm is to have people reconstruct a remembered position. A classic result is that stronger chess players are better than weaker ones, as long as the position is a real chess position. We tested the analogous prediction in our paradigm. “Expert” players (who had played our game on five separate days) did not perform differently on the reconstruction task than novice players, even though they played stronger in the game itself. This dissociates reconstruction ability from planning.

 

In the reporting period, we also finished the manuscript that contains all experiments. It is currently close to submission.

 

In the reporting period, we also expanded on a publicly accessible website that contains demos of most experiments, example data, and one key paper produced by the project. The website is https://basvanopheusden.github.io.  

 

The main trainee on this project, Sebastiaan (Bas) van Opheusden, successfully defended his PhD thesis on October 29, 2018, based on the results of this project.

 

Looking back at the entire project, we consider the research goals largely met: we have an extensively validated computational process model of how people plan ahead when the decision tree is large. We can account for a wide range of data (moves, reaction times, eye movements, and mouse movements). We have characterized what changes occur in human reasoning as they acquire expertise in the game.

 

In terms of broader impacts, the award has given the Principal Investigator, Dr. Ma, the opportunity to do extensive outreach and advocacy. Over the lifetime of the award, he has given guest lectures about mind and brain: a) on Career Day at North Star Academy High School in Newark NJ (three times), b) at Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan, c) to middle school students from underrepresented minority groups in the context of NYU’s CRISP program, d) at a booth during Brain Awareness Week, e) during the World Science Festival, f) to the NYU Parents Council, and g) at three venues in the Netherlands. He also led neuroscience outreach events at Caveat in New York City (twice). He helped found the Science Action and Advocacy Network (www.scaan.net), which works with non-profit organizations to make psychology and neuroscience research relevant to social causes; he is still a leader in this organization. Finally, he spoke at the March for Science NYC on April 14, 2018.
